data.title: simplewords8
data.text:
Well, how’s everyone doing this week? I’m excited as this is the fourth and final post for the first half of the semester.

This week we will talk about the fourth pattern, Rich User Experience (RUE) out of the eight care patterns of Tim O’Reilly.

What do Rick User Experience mean?

Rich user experience means that applications are more interactive, dynamic, and pervasive. How does this work? From what I do understand from Wikipedia, Rich Internet Applications (RIA) work more like desktop applications compared to traditional web applications. For example, like static mapping and webmail application. Technology such as Ajax and Adobe Flex are enabled by this new technology.

Let’s talk about some examples of great websites that has Rich User Experience.

Google Chrome is one of the example. Compare to traditional browser, it’s just a browser where user could just browse the web and nothing more could be done. When Google Chrome came into the market, it could do more than just browse the web. It could be customised with different customised background and have different themes. More than that, it could download apps from the Google Web Store. In Google Web Store, there are different categories of apps that could be downloaded such as social network, news & weather, education, entertainment, and many more.

Benefits

The benefit of this feature is that it could satisfy many other more users out there. By saying that, it will also lower down the percentage of user abandoning the web browser. It totally also win all the other competition out there in market.

Best Practices

It ultimately combine the best of desktop and online experience for all users out there. In terms of desktop, it will have higher user engagement, faster performance, and richer interactive between users and the site. However in terms of network, it has it’s own platform independence, ubiquitous access for all different users, and collaboration.

In terms of usability and simplicity, the main focus was on user that means efficiency for user comes first. That’s the reason that apps were created and integrated into Chrome.

Conclusion

All in all, the evolution of web 2.0 of Rich User Experience had changed the way user browse the Internet and website. It ease and made the experience so much better and more interesting.

Reference:

Tim O’Reilly

Rich Internet Application

Google Chrome

Google Web Store

Overview

In this generation or millennium, we do know that Internet plays an important part in our lives. We use Internet for everything. For example, we use Google Map when we drive, we use YouTube to learn how to cook new dishes, we use Instagram to share pictures with our peers, we use mobile app to do Internet banking and many more. Have you ever realise that Internet or Technology is growing rapidly and it’s tougher for human to catch up on? Well, the concept behind it is innovation in assembly.

What’s behind all these websites are called Application Programming Interface (API). What does it do is that it specifies the software component should interact with each other. For example, when a user wants to access the hard drive, API will connect with the software and produce a visual that is understandable for user.

eBay has one of the best APIs among all websites.

Benefits & Best Practices

Submit items for listing on eBay.

Users could list their item on eBay to sell.

Get the current list of eBay categories.

Buyers could search items through list as well.

View information about items listed on eBay.

Buyers could view information about the item listed before purchasing.

Get high bidder information for items you are selling.

Seller could get high bidder information upon selling the item.

Leave feedback about other users at the conclusion of a commerce transaction.

Buyers and seller could leave feedback to the other party after a commerce transaction had been done.

Issues & Debates

Some sellers might not do a full refund to buyer despite item did not received successfully to buyer. That is a problem with some sellers that do not care regarding the feedback they received from buyers.

The total cost might not be the price seller fixed as there might be shipping/postage fee that require buyer to pay for. Some buyer might not be aware with that and purchase blindly. That might cause buyer to lose their trust in using eBay or future usage.

Conclusion

eBay is a great online service with great API that’s working behind the scene. It definitely will take some time to reach the current status. Nevertheless, I believe eBay will continue to improve their APIs along the years to come.

Reference:

TechCrunch

Wikipedia

O’reilly

Hi all. Hope everyone is doing great. This week’s topic is the second core out of the Eight Core Patterns that was defined by Tim O’Reilly‘s that I’m going to talk about and that is Data is the next “Intel Inside”.

What do “data is the next intel inside” means?

From what I understand is that softwares like Photoshop, Microsoft Word, iTunes, and etc, these software do not require any data but just input from the particular user. However if you look at YouTube, Facebook, or even LinkedIn, all these software or application requires data to be more intelligent. Aren’t you amazed how YouTube or Facebook could identify which country are you at and cater advertisements that might interest you? That is where data comes to play. Those data that users provide to the system or application is used as an important data, short for Intel.

Let’s take a look at Eventful. It’s a global calendar that tells users what are the events that’s happening around them.

It’s based on users whereby users could create an event and could share it with their friends via email newsletter or the website itself. Other users could also search for the event locally through the search bar. The website targets users based on their interest to advertise and promote the event. It’s similar approach to websites like Amazon or Ebay as other Web 2.0 websites.

Benefits of this application is that company do not need to spend heaps on advertisements around town just to create awareness. In result, it would create more revenues in that event. Besides that, greater customer loyalty and buy-in via their own data creation. Event companies then would have a database of personal information of every attendees.

This way it enables the system to reuse the information that users input in their interest. Data that are collected are being used by shooting out events that ticks the interest of users’.

Of course by creating a profile in Eventful, users have to agree with the terms and conditions. By agreeing with the terms and condition, Eventful has the ability to use those data given by users and use it for commercial interest to match events to users. Apart from that, users have the power to take down the data from the Eventful by deleting the account.

References:

How Stuff Works

Wikipedia

Tim O’Reilly

Eventful

Hey everyone! Hope everyone is doing great this week! This week’s topic is “Harnessing Collective Intelligence“. Harnessing Collective Intelligence is a concept that was first defined by Tim O’Reilly. It actually revolves around network effects and user participation. That means other user of the site and themselves had the benefit as users collaboration with the website had provided useful data. The simple way to say it, “The more participation from users in a particular website, the better quality of information that’s gathered by the website. Quiet a number of Web 2.0 sites that utilise such feature such as Wikipedia, Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr and Flickr. By that way, the website can provide a better user experience and could lead to increase of hits on their website.

StumbleUpon is the website that I’m going to talk about. Well, just a little history about StumbleUpon. According to Wikipedia, it was founded in November 2002 by Garrett Camp, Geoff Smith, Justin LaFrance and Eric Boyd. It was a project that they had to do during their post-graduate school in Calgary, Canada.

Here’s a short clip of what StumbleUpon is all about.

The concept of StumbleUpon is to collect and learn input that user gives (likes or dislike from results produced) and learn it to create a better opinion in the future for users.

How to operates? First you have to create an account in order to use that service. Once you’ve done that, insert all your information and interest such as music, food, animals, etc, then you click on a button to stumble to a random site. What the site does is it searches random websites that has mutual focus based on your interest that you provided in your profile. Then you’ll be given the power to like or dislike the page and make any comments on the content. The act of like or dislike contributes to the quality of recommendations for you. There’s an option to share via other social media websites, like Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn to your peers.

The main objective of this website is pretty clear with collecting data from the information that users provided that’s called user collaboration or collective intelligence.

In the future with more users and the amount of information that was provided such as the ratings like or dislike of the results given to users. With all those information the system will understand more of user’s preference in the future. In result, it will produce a higher quality result and choices for all users.

I guess one major disadvantage about this is that when a user provides random data to the system and simply evaluate the rates for the websites, it will turn things upside down. The result produced by the system do depends on user’s input and with different input do produce different outcome as well.

In conclusion, StumbleUpon is successful in harnesses collective intelligence via users ratings on different websites associated with user’s results. This assists the site to improve their results and recommendations to users.

References:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/StumbleUpon

http://oreilly.com/pub/a/web2/archive/what-is-web-20.html?page=2

http://demo.telenovo.com/uploads/groups_bull/files/30/decision%202.0.pdf
